timeline.author: Sammers21
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,5 @@
+# Contributor Code of Conduct
+
+This project adheres to No Code of Conduct.  We are all adults.  We accept anyone's contributions.  Nothing else matters.

replies.bodyText: @Sammers21 GitHub doesn't think so, it asks to add such file
replies.author: g4s8

replies.bodyText: @g4s8, A code of conduct is a set of rules outlining the norms, rules, and responsibilities or proper practices of an individual party or an organisation. We work with zerocrat and have specific rules. Mention them in the file. Now the file does not bring any value.
replies.author: Sammers21

replies.bodyText: @Sammers21 we don't work by Zerocracy rules, only users from 0crat.com do. But they are aware about these rules without this file.
replies.author: g4s8

timeline.bodyText: I think this file is not related to the pull request
timeline.author: Sammers21
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1,22 +0,0 @@
-This document contains code style decisions which may be treated as opinion based, and can't
-be caught by static code analyzers.
-To avoid long PR discussions we'll document it here.
-This document will be updated on demand, when we get new opinion based issue about coding style.
-
-1. Prefer Hamcrest matchers objects instead of static methods in unit tests:
-```java
-// use
-MatcherAssert.assertThat(target, new IsEquals<>(expected));
-
-// don't use
-MatcherAssert.assertThat(target, Matchers.isEquals(expected));
-```
-
-2. Avoid adding reason to assertions in unit tests with single assertion:
-```java
-// use
-MatcherAssert.assertThat(target, matcher);
-
-// don't use
-MatcherAssert.assertThat("Some reason", target, matcher);
-```

replies.bodyText: @Sammers21 CODE_STYLE.md is not a standard GitHub file, so it was moved to CONTRIBUTING.md which is the standard file and GitHub displays a reference when submitting pull request.
replies.author: g4s8

timeline.author: Sammers21
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,63 @@
+To contribute to Artipie project you need JDK-11 and Maven 3.2+.

replies.bodyText: @Sammers21 reference to what? I suppose contributors are able to install Java and Maven by themselves, also there are no standard links for that - each OS distribution has its own package for Java and Maven.
replies.author: g4s8

replies.bodyText: @g4s8, for jdk 11 you can refer to https://adoptopenjdk.net/ or https://jdk.java.net/11/. For maven, you can refer to https://maven.apache.org/
replies.author: Sammers21

timeline.bodyText: Invalid link for reference. Use this one: https://docs.github.com/en/github/collaborating-with-issues-and-pull-requests/about-pull-requests
timeline.author: Sammers21
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,63 @@
+To contribute to Artipie project you need JDK-11 and Maven 3.2+.
+Some integration tests requires Docker to be installed.
+
+
+## How to contribute
+
+Fork the repository, make changes, and send us a
+[pull request](https://www.yegor256.com/2014/04/15/github-guidelines.html). We will review

replies.bodyText: @Sammers21 the link you have provided just explains what pull request is but not how to use it properly.
replies.author: g4s8

replies.bodyText: @g4s8, The only mention of pull requests in the article refers to the exact Github link I sent above:
replies.author: Sammers21
